Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Instrument: High-Bandwidth Network Connectivity for Remote Sensing Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific instruments can produce vast amounts of data. Besides capturing and storing data, it is important to give the global research community fast access to this data. In the case of remote sensing instruments like Doppler weather radar the challenges such instruments face in terms of connecting them to high-bandwidth networks is the fact that they have to be placed outside the lab at locations that are well suited for their sensing tasks, which are often not close to high-bandwidth networking infrastructure. For example, a radar is ideally placed at a location that is free of any obstructions such that it can scan the atmosphere with as little interference as possible.

The overarching goal of this project is to improve research that focuses on remote sensing by providing researchers the ability to transmit high-bandwidth time-series or spectral data, and analog signals via radio over fiber, in real time from sensors to remote storage and computing. The project improves connectivity from an on-campus tower hosting radar and other atmospheric sensors to the UMass Amherst computer network. A fiber connection is established between the tower and the main campus network with local storage capacity increases to 8 TB at the tower. This integration permits several new modes of real time data analysis for weather system research and allows for both more data to be captured and for more timely access to data.

Improving atmospheric observations has significant impacts on weather modeling in general and weather warning and prediction in particular. Thus this project has the potential to support applications that increase the safety and security of US communities and the nation as a whole. In addition, this campus network infrastructure opens new opportunities for students. For example, students can obtain live analog or high-bandwidth time series radar data to experiment with.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific instruments can produce vast amounts of data. Besides capturing and storing data, it is important to give the global research community fast access to these data. In the case of remote sensing instruments like Doppler weather radar the challenges the research community faces in terms of connecting them to high-bandwidth networks is the fact that they have to be placed outside the lab at locations that are well suited for their sensing tasks, which are often not close to high-bandwidth networking infrastructure. For example, radars are ideally placed at locations that are free of any obstructions such that it can scan the atmosphere with as little interference as possible.

The overarching goal of this project is to improve research that focuses on remote sensing by providing researchers the ability to transmit high-bandwidth time-series or spectral data, and analog signals via fiber-optical links, in real time from sensors to remote storage and computing. The project improves connectivity from an on-campus tower hosting radar and other atmospheric sensors to the UMass Amherst campus network. As part of the project, a fiber connection has been established between the tower and the main campus network. This integration permits several new modes of real time data analysis for weather warning and detection research and allows for both more data to be captured and for more timely access to data. 

Due to the high bandwidth link enabled by the fiber between the radar tower and the campus network time series radar data from a variety of experiments could be streamed to and analyzed in real time on compute equipment housed in a data center on campus. Before the installation of the fiber link the only means of communication between the tower and the campus network was a 802.11 wireless link. Caused by the limitations of the wireless link researchers had to collect data locally at the tower and analyze them later. With the new high-bandwidth link in place, data can be streamed to compute equipment (located in a campus data center) and analyzed in real time. This allows researchers to analyze data from an ongoing experiment in real time and adjust radar operations if necessary. This feature is of significant importance when it comes to experiments that involve weather observations. Certain phenomena like tornadoes only rarely occur, and once the opportunity is given to scan such an event, researchers want to be able to observe radar data in real time and make adjustments to the sensing system if necessary. This feature supported researchers when they had the opportunity to scan a tornado on October 23rd 2019. The new cyberinfrastructure also supported work on radar-based drone detection and tracking, where the capability of real-time data transmission is equally important. In addition, the high-bandwidth network connection now allows for the simultaneous transmission of data from more than one radar. This has enabled the deployment of a phased-array radar alongside a traditional radar with a dish antenna. Finally, the National Weather Service (NWS) forecast offices in Albany and Boston showed interest in the reflectivity and velocity data generated by the traditional weather radar. The lowest coverage by the existing NWS NEXRAD weather radars is on the order of 5000 – 6000 feet in Western Massachusetts. Data from the UMass radar provides the NWS with information from that region that is much closer to the ground. Based on data from several severe storms the NWS decided to provide a permanent data feed from the radar to both, the Albany and the Boston forecast offices. The high-bandwidth network connection to the radar tower allows the reliable and timely transmission of weather observations from the radar to both forecast offices which contributes to the NWS’ ability to better observe weather in that region.
